fields.summary: CC registration: cloud-pk.pem is not transferred to remote cluster, and CC shutdown will not tear down network rules

fields.description: Even after clean-stop, the ex-ENABLED CC node still keeps Eucalyptus public IP address/Private Gateway IPs and iptables content, same IP addresses are bonded on both CC nodes.
fields.summary: CC cleanstop does not clean up iptables

comments.body:
Both the customer and I are using two computers for the front end,  and separate NC's.
Starting point is to have HA up and running in a healthy state. several instances are running and accessible.

Test: Log into the enabled CC and issuing a cleanstop on the cc ( service eucalyputus-cc cleanstop )
Symptom:
- The CC that was disabled transitions to enabled correctly.
- The CC that was cleanstopped shows a state of NOTREADY, Is this the expected state? should the state not be STOPPED?
- The CC that was cleanstopped still retains it's original iptables rules.

Now we have two systems that have the same private IP address, and iptables rules. We also observed intermittent packet loss under these conditions. Further, we suspect that if new instances are started, that the iptables will not remain in sync and may result in further network issues for the instances.

When the cc is started, then the IP tables are cleaned up and normal, healthy operation resumes.


Test summary follow:

collaborated with Graziano to replicate this issue
Can we get clarification.  Is the behavior for cleanstop to clear iptables or is it to just clear whats in memory?  I thought it was a cleanstart that was supposed to actually clear iptables?

I am not sure what you are looking for here?  Do you just want clarification on cleanstop/cleanstart behavior?

What are the exact steps to reproduce this?

I am not able to reproduce this issue, I see the ip tables getting cleared on a cleanstop?

This is my setup:
machine00	RHEL	6.2	64	BZR	[CLC WS CC00 SC00]
machine01	RHEL	6.2	64	BZR	[CLC WS CC00 SC00]
machine02	RHEL	6.2	64	BZR	[NC00]

I did the following on the enabled CC:

1 euca-describe-services  (this populates the iptables) 
2 iptables-save ( this shows PREROUTING to running instances )
3 service eucalyptus-cc cleanstop
4 iptables-save  ( PREROUTING to running instances cleaned out )
5 service eucalyptus-cc start ( not even cleanstart) 
6 iptables-save  ( PREROUTING to running instances still not there )
7 euca-describe-services  (this populates the iptables again )

What am I missing?
I need to know exactly how you reproduced this issue?
I am going to close this as not reproducible.
I cannot reproduce this issue. I see the iptables being cleaned. You can reopen this when and if you have a reproducible testcase

Interesting. I retested this on version 3.1.1 and now the iptables are being cleaned up upon a clean stop. Will advise the customer that this issue has been addressed in 3.1.1. Thank you.

Reopening the issue as it is seen at customer site.
I will take a look at this in 3.1.2 and 3.2 both Neil Beard and I were not able to reproduce this in 3.1.1.
I cannot reproduce this issue please provide the exact steps you used.
cannot reproduce

Easily reproducible on will, just reproduced this in the lab. Details.

Step 1) Setup a cloud using following

machine 1: CLC/Walrus , Primary
machine 2: CLC/Walrus , Secondary
machine 3: CC , Primary
machine 4: CC , Secondary
machine 5: SC 
machine 6: NC

Install eucalyptus 3.1.2 from CentOS 6.3 packages

Step 2) 

make sure, Primary is the one that is ENABLED for CLC/WALRUS/CC and Secondary is the one that is DISABLED.

Step 3)

Run an instance on the cloud, once the instance status shows "Running", cleanstop eucalyptus-cc on the Primary/ENABLED CC.

Step 4)

Wait for sometime and keep checking "ip addr show" and iptables-save on the cleanstopped CC as well as the ENABLED (now) CC.

cleanstop CC, ip addr show

{code}

3: em2: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state UP qlen 1000
